column4: the evolution bug you had me report upstream, is there a way to doc that somewhere so other ubuntu users will know upstream is taking care of it and it's a known prob?
not yet, but there will be :)
fyi, contacts and evolution-alarm is broken on amd64 platform and according to upstream it's most likely a libdb threading problem
excellent, that's the best response we get :-) thanks
it took a little longer to install all the development tools I use, but it was still pretty easy once I uncommented universal and restricted in apt sources.list ;)
what did I need from universe?
i needed anjuta, allegro, and a few other things from universe/restricted
most distributions include allegro in their base already along with sdl
'****house properietary drivers' are better than none, and in some cases are the only option, you know that as well as I do if you do commercial software development
they are, but if companies persist with binary drivers, they will lose in the market.
i'm not so sure, 3d graphics are an area where I doub't well ever see good 3d hardware with drivers :|
even ati went closed source :|
dude, it will happen. it is inevitable. :-)
when linux has 20% market share, do you think the dells, hps and ibms of this world are going to choose hardware/chipsets that require binary drivers? no. :-)

the pie in the sky idea of one day properietary drives won't be necessary because we'll own the market sounds great, but in the meantime binary 3d is the only way to get workstation class 3d so it'd be great if that were easier :)
that's a *good* thing :-)
not from a programming perspective
if the Qt or Gtk apis changed as often as the kernel driver API there would be a mutiny :)
even for open source drivers it's very difficult to keep up with kernel changes sometimes
sure, that's why they should be in the kernel
that sounds great in theory, but what about when there's 20,000 drivers to be maintained
pretend for a moment that binary drivers couldn't exist
would you then suddenly want  a stable API?
